sentence: At the tail end of the first-quarter earnings season, all eyes are on retail stocks, the bulk of which are about to come out with their financial releases.

Despite a competitive environment, unfavorable weather conditions when the year begun, West Coast port unrest and ongoing currency headwinds, the sector has had a decent run so far in the season, with a few exceptions.

Retailers such as J. C. Penney Company, Inc. JCP , Leggett & Platt, Incorporated LEG , Church & Dwight Co. Inc. CHD , Skechers USA Inc. SKX and Herbalife Ltd. HLF witnessed positive earnings surprises of 27.9%, 8.7%, 2.6%, 8.9% and 29%, respectively.
On the contrary, Macy's, Inc. M , Nordstrom Inc. JWN and Lumber Liquidators Holdings, Inc. LL fell short of their respective Zacks Consensus Estimate.
The retail sector swings with the economy -- which came to a screeching halt during the first quarter of 2015 when GDP barely expanded 0.2%, falling shy of analysts' expectation of 1% growth.
Yet the economy fared better than the first quarter of 2014, when GDP faltered 2.1%.
But the strength of 2.2%, 5% and 4.6% GDP growth in the fourth, third and second quarter of 2014, respectively, was clearly missing.
The silver lining to the recent run of soft economic readings is the Fed angle, with the central bank expected to hold off rate increases for the time being.
Despite this slowdown, economists still believe that the underlying fundamentals are strong enough to drive the economy.
They expect the economy to grow at a pace of about 3% in 2015.
Gradual recovery in the housing market, a strengthening manufacturing sector, an improving labor market and lower gasoline prices are favoring the economy and boosting consumers' purchasing power.
As temporary factors, such as harsh weather and port unrest take a back seat, the economy will bounce back, although it may have to endure a stronger dollar for some time.

Unemployment rate is currently hovering around 5.4%, the lowest since mid-2008, while recent data shows that the number of people claiming unemployment benefits for the first time dropped 1,000 for the week ended May 9, to a seasonally adjusted 264,000.
Claims for unemployment benefits touched a 15-year low during the week.
With the economy likely to strengthen, the labor market set to improve further and consumer spending to increase, the retail sector will be the beneficiary.
But for the time being, you can wrap up your Q1 earnings season with 3 retail stocks that are likely to beat earnings estimates when they report this week.
We have identified the stocks based on Zacks' Profitable Mix formula: Favorable Zacks Rank - Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy), #2 (Buy) or #3 (Hold) - and a positive Zacks Earnings ESP .
Our research shows that for stocks with this combination, the chance of a positive earnings surprise is as high as 70%.
A favorable rank indicates positive estimate revisions by analysts optimistic on the future performance of companies.
Moreover, Earnings ESP is our proprietary methodology for identifying stocks that have the best chance to surprise with their next earnings announcement.
The Home Depot, Inc.HD is a Zacks Rank #3 stock having an Earnings ESP of +0.87%.
The current Zacks Consensus Estimate for the first quarter of fiscal 2015 is $1.15 per share, portraying 14.9% growth from the prior-year quarter.
This Atlanta, GA-based home improvement retailer, registered an average positive earnings beat of 5.4% over the trailing four quarters, and has a long-term earnings growth rate of 14.1%.
The company is slated to report on May 19.
Dick's Sporting Goods Inc.DKS is a Zacks Rank #3 stock having an Earnings ESP of +3.77%.
The current Zacks Consensus Estimate for the first quarter of fiscal 2015 is 53 cents a share, and reflects 5.1% growth year over year.
This Coraopolis, PA-based sporting goods retailer, experienced an average earnings beat of 1.6% over the trailing four quarters, and has a long-term earnings growth rate of 13.5%.
The company is slated to report on May 19.
Lowe's Companies Inc.LOW is also a Zacks Rank #3 stock with an Earnings ESP of +2.70%.
The current Zacks Consensus Estimate for the first quarter of fiscal 2015 is 74 cents a share, depicting 27.7% growth from the prior-year period.
This Mooresville, NC-based home improvement retailer, witnessed an average positive earnings beat of 0.8% over the trailing four quarters, and has a long-term earnings growth rate of 15.9%.

The company is scheduled to report on May 20.
